Graphical abstract Hydrogenolysis of lignocellulose into renewable phenolic monomers through the reductive catalytic degradation (RCD) strategy is limited by cost and applicability, and there is a need to develop effective catalysts with controlled cost and greater applicability. Herein, we report the fabrication of CuO/CeO2 catalyst toward RCD of lignocellulose for the production of monomeric phenols with different side chains. The catalyst can be adapted to softwoods (Larch and Pinus) and hardwoods (Eucalyptus and Poplar) with yields ranging from 8.8 % to 31.4 %, which afford certain monomer yields while controlling costs. Experimental results demonstrate that the acidic and basic sites of the CuO/CeO2 catalyst assist the metal sites in the depolymerization of lignin. Notably, the mechanistic investigation reveal that the methoxylation process occurs on the aliphatic hydroxyl group. Moreover, the synergistic effects of hydrogen and catalyst exhibit high hydrogenolysis activity, which contributes to the efficient C − O bond scission, thus generating the target monomer products. Keywords Lignin Monomeric phenol Reductive catalytic deconstruction C−O bond scission Cu-based catalyst Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Current carbon emissions mainly come from the utilization of energy, so it has become a hotpot of research to reduce the dependence on fossil resources and establish a renewable energy-led, and multi-energy complementary energy system [1,2]. Lignocellulose is a valuable renewable resource owing to its short growth cycle and widespread throughout the natural world [3,4]. Traditional biorefinery technologies focus on cellulose and hemicellulose fractions, with little attention given to lignin [5–9]. Lignin accounts for approximately 20 ∼ 30 % of lignocellulose, composed of three structures of phenylpropane units linked by C − O bonds (∼70 %) and C − C bonds (∼30 %) [10]. The hydrogenolysis of lignin provides an effective way to add value to lignin, and the degradation products have high added-value for applications [11–13]. However, the irreversible formation of unsaturated double bonds and some breakage of C − O bonds may occur during the separation of lignocellulose, which results in low yields of monomeric phenols from the lignin samples [8]. Lignin first strategy is among the most common and productive process for generating aromatic products from native lignin in biomass while retaining (hemi)cellulose for further use [14,15]. Monomeric phenols bearing allyl alcohol-based side chains are generally considered to be the first monomer products generated in the reductive catalytic degradation (RCD) of lignin prone to re-condensation reactions [16–18]. Due to its high bond cleavage energy, breaking the C − O bond under moderate conditions is a huge challenge. Metal catalysts are extensively employed in the RCD of lignocellulose, such as Ru [19–21], Pd [22–24], Rh [25,26], Pt [27], Cu [28–30], Mo [31], and Ni [3]. For example, Co(Ni)/MoO3 catalyst was employed to catalytic hydrogenolysis of biomass derivative, breaking the C − O linkages to produce aromatic products [32]. The Ru-catalyzed oxidative reduction of 2-aryl-1-arylethanol gave a yield of 62 ∼ 98 % of the cleaved product [33]. Loaded metal catalysts are used in industrial catalytic applications due to their sufficient active sites and high availability of atoms [34–37]. Hydrogenation of pyrolytic lignin carried out over Ru/TiO2 catalyst with the significant conversion of carboxyl/carbonyl and aromatic carbons to aliphatic carbons [38]. Au1Pd1/CeO2 has been reported toward effective transformation of lignin into valuable monophenols in 44.1 % yield [39]. High selectivity of ethylbenzene from lignin model compounds (78.5 %) and birch lignin oil (63.4 %) was achieved over RuFe/Nb2O5 catalysts [40]. Although much progress has been made, there is still an acute requirement for more active and selective catalytic hydrogenolysis of lignin. The application of noble metal catalysts is limited by the prohibitive cost and the fact that the noble metal active component is not conducive to the passivation of the depolymerization intermediates and is prone to over-hydrogenation [41]. To tackle these problems, developing non-precious metal catalysts for the RCD of lignocellulose into value-added aromatics has become increasingly important [42–45]. Amongst the non-precious metal catalysts, copper-based catalysts are preferred due to their high activity and selectivity. The loaded copper metal catalyst has great potential for lignin hydrogenolysis. It is well established that the importance of the metal-support interface supported by Ce-based catalysis is well documented, with the particle size of cerium giving definition to the structure of the metal-support interface and the attachment of metal particles being retained by strong metal-support bonds [46–49]. In this work, CeO2-supported CuO catalyst (CuO/CeO2) was synthesized, which was effective for the RCD of natural woody biomass, including Poplar, Eucalyptus, Larch and Pinus. This novel catalyst can be applied to woody lignin to obtain a range of monomeric phenols with different side chains. The process of methoxylation of aliphatic hydroxyl groups and cleavage of C − O bonds are described during the hydrogenolysis process of lignin model compounds over the CuO/CeO2 catalyst. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Material Ce(NO3)3·6H2O (99.5 %) and Cu(OAc)2·H2O (99.0 %) were purchased from Macklin. Methanol was purchased from Energy Chemical. Poplar, Eucalyptus, Larch and Pinus were extracted, crushed and screened into powders in size of 40 ∼ 60 meshes (0.5 mm ∼ 1.0 mm) and dried vacuum at 50 °C for 72 h before use. 2.2 Catalyst preparation Generally, CeO2 was achieved by calcinating Ce(NO3)3·6H2O at 350 °C in air for 2 h [50]. 0.25 g CeO2 (1.45 mmol) support was dispersed into 50 mL of methanol by sonication for 0.5 h. Then 0.58 g Cu(OAc)2·H2O (2.90 mmol) was added into the above system and kept stirring at 25 °C for 1 h, which was designated as solution A. A fresh solution of NaBH4/MeOH (1.45 mg/mL) was designated as solution B. Subsequently, solution B was rapidly mixed solution A with a mechanical stirring for 2.5 h. The obtained precipitate was then filtered and washed 3 times with methanol. After drying at 60 °C overnight, the calcination process was carried out at 600 °C in air for 2 h. 2.3 Preparation for double enzymatic lignin (DEL) Typically, ball-milled Poplar wood powder (5 g) was suspended in 100 mL acetate buffer (pH 4.8) with loading of 2.5 mL of cellulase (100 FPU/mL). The reaction mixture was incubated at 50 °C in a rotary shaker (150 rpm) for 48 h. After that, the mixture was centrifuged, and the residual solid was washed extensively with acetate buffer (pH 4.8) and hot water and then freeze-dried. The dried residual solid was further subjected to the ball-milling process for 2 h and enzymatic hydrolysis as in the above-mentioned procedures. After washing and lyophilization, the DEL samples were obtained. 2.4 RCD process for woody biomass Generally, woody sawdust (50 mg), CuO/CeO2 (20 mg) and solvent (10 mL) were loaded into a 50 mL Parr autoclave and hydrogen gas was introduced at 3 MPa. The reaction was carried out at different temperatures for a time. At the end of the reaction, the reactor was carefully depressurized after cooling to room temperature. The products were soluble (lignin oil) and insoluble (carbohydrate and catalyst) fractions. Subsequently, the soluble fractions were extracted with dichloromethane and all volatiles were removed under vacuum and then analyzed quantitatively and qualitatively by gas chromatography (GC) and gas chromatography-mass spectrometry (GC–MS), respectively. 2.5 Measurements X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns were gathered over a 2θ range from 10° to 80° with a 5°/min scan rate and 0.02° step size using the XRD-6100 diffractometer of Shimazu Laboratory. Only the graphs in the useful range are included in this work. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) analysis was performed using a Thermo Scientific K-alpha plus spectrometer, calibrated using a C 1 s binding energy of 284.6 eV. High resolution transmission electron microscope (HR-TEM) images were captured with an FEI Talos F200x G2 microscope operated at an accelerating voltage of 200 kV. Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) images were collected with a JEOL 630-F microscope. Inductively coupled plasma atomic emission spectroscopy (ICP-AES) was applied to measure the copper and cerium content of the CuO/CeO2. H2 temperature-programmed reduction (H2-TPR) were collected with a Micromeritics Autochem 2920 instrument·NH3 temperature-programmed desorption (NH3-TPD) and CO2 temperature-programmed desorption (CO2-TPD) were used to analyze the acid and base sites of the catalyst, respectively. X-ray absorption fine structure (XAFS) measurements were performed at the Cu K-edge, which were performed based on a previous literature [51]. We use wavelet transform (WT) to process Extended x-ray absorption fine structure (EXAFS) data. Molecular weight (Mw) distributions of samples were ascertained by gel permeation chromatography (GPC). Seven GPC polystyrene standards (124 ∼ 26520 g/mol) purchased from Agilent (Agilent Technologies, Inc., Santa Clara, CA) were used for calibration. Lignin oil as well as lignin samples were dissolved in tetrahydrofuran (THF) solvent (2 mg/mL) and filtered through a 0.45 μm polytetrafluoroethylene filter prior to injection. The characterization and quantification of lignin monomers in lignin oil were analyzed by Gas chromatography (GC) and Gas chromatography-mass spectrometry (GC–MS). The solvent peak (DMSO‑d 6) at δC/δH 39.5/2.49 was used as an internal reference in the 13C–1H heteronuclear singular quantum correlation nuclear magnetic resonance (2D HSQC NMR) spectra [31,52–56]. The detailed steps for the characterization and analysis are provided in the supporting information. 3 Result and discussion 3.1 Characterization of the catalyst The diagram for synthesis of the CuO/CeO2 catalyst is shown in Fig. 1 a. To identify the properties of the prepared catalyst and how it affects the catalytic performance, we have used a range of characterization techniques to assist in elucidating. The weight percentage of elemental copper and cerium are approximately 41.1 % and 42.8 % based on ICP-AES analysis, respectively (Table S6). The catalyst retained the typical cubic fluorite structure of CeO2 (PDF#43–1002) carrier, which suggested the introduction of the Cu species did not alter the structure of CeO2 (Fig. 1b). The HR-TEM image synergistically confirmed that the cerium retained its original crystal shape after the introduction of CuO (Fig. S2 b). Meanwhile, the diffraction peaks at 35.5°, 38.7°, 48.7°, 61.5° are attributed to (11–1), (110), (20–2), (11–3) of CuO, respectively (PDF#48–1548). The planar spacing of the CeO2 nanoparticles was identified as 0.31 nm, corresponding to the 220 planes, while the 11–1 planes (0.25 nm) were determined for CuO (Fig. 2b), which were in agreement with the XRD analysis. The XPS spectra of CuO/CeO2 catalyst revealed two peaks at 934.3 eV and 955.2 eV are attributed to CuO, respectively (Fig. 1c), and the satellite peak (∼940 ∼ 945 eV) indicates the presence of Cu2+ species in the sample [57]. The slightly higher binding energy of the samples than the reported data for pure CuO might be due to the transfer of Cu binding energy resulting from the interaction between CeO2 and CuO. The 880 ∼ 920 eV spectral feature matches the Ce 3d core levels with the two main and four satellite peaks of Ce (3d5/2, 3/2), which were associated with the Ce (IV) initial state of CeO2 (Fig. S3 a). Fig. 2e showed the H2-TPR curve for CeO2 and CuO/CeO2 catalyst. Notably, CeO2 exhibited two reduction peaks (blue line), of which the reduction peak at lower temperature is ascribed to the reduction of surface oxygen in CeO2, whereas the higher one was ascribed to the reduction of bulk oxygen [58]. In case of the CuO/CeO2 catalyst, the reduction peak at 200 °C is due to the reduction of CuO and partial cerium at the CuO-CeO2 interface [59,60]. The significantly lower reduction temperature of CuO/CeO2 in comparison with that of bulk CeO2 was probably own to the fact that copper could effectively activate the Ce-O bond on the surface, leading to the surface reduction of CeO2 [61]. The metal site has the ability to cleave the ether bond, while the base site has the ability to assist in hydrogenolysis reaction [62,63]. CO2-TPD analysis displayed in Fig. 2f and the BET analysis (Table S7) indicated that the addition of Cu resulted in a notable reduction in surface area as relative to the support, without significantly reducing its adsorption capacity [64]. Peaks located at 100 ∼ 150 °C displayed weakly basic peak and were considered to be the hydroxyl groups on the surface of CuO [65]. NH3-TPD experiments were conducted to examine the surface acid strength on the catalyst (Fig. S3b). The shift in desorption temperature toward lower temperatures for NH3 as compared to CeO2 indicated that loading CuO on CeO2 support reduced its surface acid properties with the weak acid sites, which promoted lignin depolymerization without causing severe recondensation of the intermediates [66,67]. The acidic and basic sites of CuO/CeO2 changed its surface properties, where the metal ions were surrounded by oxygen ions to form a lattice structure. Accordingly, the oxygen atoms of the metal oxide displayed a strong electrophilic force. The existence of the alkaline sites made the CuO/CeO2 catalyst revealed the ability to accept protons. In addition, Lweis acidic sites could help the catalyst accept lone electron pairs. In the process of hydrogenolysis reaction, the acidic and alkaline sites of the catalyst could adsorb lignin macromolecules and regulate its reactivity with solvents to promote the reaction. The correlation EXAFS for the Cu K side in Fig. 3a revealed that the peaks of CuO/CeO2 (black line) was significantly different from Cu foil (blue line), but highly consistent with the CuO (red line). Furthermore, FT-EXAFS fitting was performed, as exhibited in Fig. 3b and Table S1. The fitting results indicated that the Cu–O coordination of the first shell was close to 4, which was similar to the coordination number of CuO crystals (Table S1). We used WT to analyze the localization of the EXAFS signal as illustrated in Fig. 3c and 3d. The spectrogram of the CuO/CeO2 catalyst was highly consistent with CuO, which combined with XPS analysis. 3.2 Reductive catalytic degradation of lignocellulose The mass fraction of phenolic monomers was determined based on the amount of lignin in the raw material, which were analyzed for chemical composition (Table S8) [43]. At the end of the reaction, the reactor was naturally cooled to room temperature and carefully depressurized. The reaction mixture was subjected to solid–liquid separation using a sand tray funnel. The soluble fraction was rich in lignin phenolic monomers and the insoluble residue contained carbohydrate slurry and catalysts. Notably, it was observed that the surface of the poplar powder was smooth before the reaction and roughly filamentous afterward, suggesting that the RCD process was preferential depolymerization of lignin (Fig. 4 c and 4d). GC and GC–MS were applied to analyze the DCM-soluble fraction (lignin oil) and to characterize as well as quantify the product by comparison with standards. The monomeric phenols containing propyl alcohol groups (S1, G1) and propyl (S2, G2) side chains were the major products in the RCD process, while small amounts of phenolic compounds containing unsaturated side chains (S3, S5) as well as ethyl side chain phenol (S4) were also obtained (Fig. 4a). Among the S derivatives, dihydrosinapyl alcohol (S1, 10.4 wt%), syringylpropane (S2, 4.7 wt%), 4-propenylsyringol (S3, 3.0 wt%), 4-ethylsyringol (S4, 1.5 wt%), and 4-allylsyringol (S5, 0.6 wt%) were identified as hydrogenolysis products. Meanwhile, for the G derivatives, dihydroconiferyl alcohol (G1, 6.0 wt%) and dihydroeugenol (G2, 1.8 wt%) were the main monomers, relying on the total lignin content of the feedstock. As illustrated in Fig. 4a, the blank assay with CeO2 (green line) exhibited a poor reactivity (∼5.8 wt% yields), while in the absence of the catalyst of CuO/CeO2 (black line) the total yield was 6.3 wt%. Notably, when the carrier was absent (blue line), the CuO catalyst exhibited an enhanced activity (18.8 wt% yields). This result provided confirmation that CuO played a main role for the selective scission of C − O bonds during the RCD process. In order to obtain evidence of successful depolymerization of lignin macromolecules in terms of molecular weight distribution, we compared the Mw of lignin oil with that of DEL. It was observed that a significant decline in Mw value (510 g/mol) in comparison with that of the pristine poplar DEL (10850 g/mol) (Fig. 4b). 2D HSQC NMR analysis clarified the typical poplar lignin structure. In addition to p-hydroxybenzoates (PB), guaiacyl (G) and syringyl (S), β-O-4′ linkages were observed as the major substructures (Fig. S27) [67,68]. The successful scission of the C − O linkages is critical in producing a high-yielding phenolic monomer. For the lignin oil, the signal of β-O-4′ aryl ether bonds were almost disappeared and gave rise to the sign of the monomeric phenol, indicating the successful depolymerization of lignin (Fig. 4e) [31]. Moreover, the dominance of propanol and propyl groups in the 2D HSQC NMR spectra was coherent with the analysis of GC. To assess the suitability of CuO/CeO2 for the RCD process, other hardwood (Eucalyptus) and softwoods (Pinus and Larch) underwent the catalytic hydrogenolysis process under the same reaction condition: sawdust (50 mg), CuO/CeO2 (20 mg), MeOH (10 mL), 3 MPa H2, 240 °C, 4 h) (Fig. 5 c; Table S18). Notably, Eucalyptus afforded a relatively high yield of monophenols (24.4 wt%) in comparison with those of softwood (8.8 ∼ 9.6 wt%). This was anticipated as softwood contained relative lower contents of β-O-4′ linkages but higher high amounts of C − C bonds [69–71]. GPC analysis showed that the lignin oils from the hydrogenolysis of various type of woody powders revealed markedly lower Mw values than those of DEL (Figs. S24 and S25). After hydrogenolysis reaction, the β-O-4′ structural signal (δC/δH 2.8 ∼ 5.3/60 ∼ 90 ppm) almost disappeared, and new phenolic monomers signal was generated in δC/δH 0.8 ∼ 2.4/10 ∼ 40 ppm (Figs. S28 ∼ S30). 3.3 Catalytic performance assessment under different reaction conditions To achieve a better understanding of the performance of CuO/CeO2, a variety of experiments were performed. Initially, we designed the catalyst by calcination under three gas atmospheres (N2, H2, and air), exploring the effect of different molar mass ratios of copper to cerium on the catalytic hydrogenolysis of poplar sawdust (Figs. S8 ∼ S13 and Tables S11-S13). The result revealed that catalyst calcined in air with a molar mass ratio of copper to cerium of 2 gave the highest monomers yield (31.4 wt%) with the lowest relative Mw value (510 g/mol). The absence of phenolic monomers with propanol or propyl side chains suggested a low reactivity of the catalysts calcined under H2 condition for hydrogenolysis reaction. Subsequently, we determined the optimum dosage of the CuO/CeO2 catalyst to be 20 mg (Table S14). Altering the reaction medium to different supercritical alcohols affected the molecular weight and structural distribution of the depolymerization products (Fig. 5a). It was suggested that the protic solvent performed a significant function in the RCD reaction over CuO/CeO2. The combined catalytic effect of the MeOH and CuO/CeO2 catalyst showed the best efficient reactivity, affording almost the maximum monomers yield (31.4 wt%) and the lowest Mw value (510 g/mol). Although the overall yield of the phenolic monomers decreased in the case of EtOH (19.4 wt%) and i PrOH (18.8 wt%), there was no significant difference on the selectivity of monomeric phenols with propyl and propanol end-chain. This result was consistent with previous work that the total monomer yield displayed an approximately linear relationship with solvent polarity [72]. Higher solvent polarity enhanced the lignocellulosic matrix and lignin solubilization, making it more accessible thus resulting in higher lignin decomposition rates [73]. We further explored the influence of various reaction times to determine the effectiveness of hydrogenolysis and found that lower reaction times might result in incomplete lignin depolymerization (Fig. 5a). Lignin condensation and lignin depolymerization occurred simultaneously during the hydrogenolysis process. Increasing the reaction time (i.e., increasing the reaction intensity) increased the extent of the recondensation reaction [74], and the condensed structure of the lignin truncates the β-O-4′ linkages so that they cannot be accessed by the CuO/CeO2 catalyst [75]. Lowering the reaction temperature from 240 °C to 200 °C and 220 °C reduced the monomer yields to 19.1 wt% and 25.0 wt% (Fig. 5b), respectively. After the reaction at 260 °C for 4 h, a slight increase in the Mw value of the lignin oil (Fig. S21) was possibly due to further condensation. As compared with other non-precious metal catalysts, CuO/CeO2 showed certain advantages in reaction conditions and monomer yield (Fig. S26). To evaluate the recyclability of the CuO/CeO2 catalyst, we characterized the spent catalyst. ICP-AES analysis yielded Cu content down to 27.4 %, and the HR-TEM image revealed Cu depletion and aggregation (Table S6 and Fig. S4a). XRD and XPS analyses collaboratively indicated that CuO was reduced to Cu after the catalyst proceeded through the hydrogenolysis reaction (Fig. S1). In summary, the decrease in active copper surface sites and the reduction of active species were the major factors contributing to catalyst deactivation. Further studies in developing higher stable Cu-based catalyst are in progress in our laboratory. 3.4 Mechanistic insights Mechanistic insights were gained by investigating the reactivity of lignin model compounds (Fig. 6 ). The formation of monophenols might be a synergistic hydrogenolysis process. We first investigated the catalytic depolymerization of phenolic β-O-4′ dimer model 1 under nitrogen atmosphere, and obtained the scission of Cβ-O bonds and the dihydroxylation of Cγ-OH. affording isoeugenol G3 (5.1 %), 2-methoxy-4-(3-methoxy-1-propenyl) phenol 2 (20.4 %), and guaiacol 3 (38.1 %) (Fig. 6a). When phenolic β-O-4′ dimer model 1 was processed at 200 °C and 3 MPa H2 with CuO/CeO2 for 4 h, the products were dihydroconiferyl alcohol G1 (12.1 %), dihydroeugenol G2 (32.1 %), and guaiacol 3 (65.1 %) together with a small amount of 4-ethylguaiacol 4 (9.4 %). The simultaneous cleavage of Cα-O and Cβ-O bonds followed by a hydrogenolysis reaction could produce monomeric phenols with propanol-based or unsaturated hydrocarbon-based side chains [24]. 2 might operate as an intermediate to form 4-propanol phenols by hydrogenation [76,77]. Moreover, it was observed that prolonged exposure of G3 to a hydrogen atmosphere also showed the potential to form saturated aliphatic side chains [78]. The effectiveness of the CuO/CeO2 catalyst toward hydrogenolysis was demonstrated by the experiments described above. Interestingly, the hydrogenolysis products of the non-phenolic β-O-4′ dimer 5 were 3 (44.2 %) and (E)-methyl isoeugenol 8 (8.3 %), in addition to 1-(3,4-dimethoxyphenyl) propane-1,3-diol 6 (7.5 %) and 1-(3′,4′-dimethoxyphenyl)-1-propanol 7 (39.3 %) (Fig. 6b). This result suggested that the aromatic-OMe group might have inhibited the departure of α-OH. The hydrogenolysis of trimer 9 formed 1-(3,4-dimethoxyphenyl) propane-1,3-diol 6 (15.1 %) and 1-(3′,4′-dimethoxyphenyl)-1-propanol 7 (21.8 %), which was also the formation of the target product G2. However, the route of reaction for model compounds with only one or two β-O-4′ units might be different from that of actual lignin. This is reasonably as multiple hydroxyl groups on lignin biopolymers possibly interact with the catalyst to affect catalytic efficiency [79]. CuO/CeO2 catalyst was further applied to the β-O-4′ polymers, where the cleavage of Cα-OH, Cβ-OH (for G1, 1.7 %) and Cγ-OH (for G2, 2.9 %) were observed followed the hydrogenolysis pathway. Moreover, a significant reduction in the Mw value indicated the successful depolymerization process (Fig. S35). Based on the studies described above, we hypothesized that the catalytic hydrogenolysis process of poplar lignin over a CuO/CeO2 could be divided into the following stages. As reported in a previous research, the α-methoxylated β-O-4′ group was observed in the early stage of the catalytic hydrogenolysis process, which was attributed to the nucleophilic substitution of some of the aliphatic hydroxyl fragments of lignin in the MeOH solvent [43,80–82]. Phenolic β-O-4′ dimer model 1 was cleaved to generate compound 2. Moreover, it was demonstrated that the Cγ position of compound 1 underwent a nucleophilic substitution reaction with MeOH to produce the γ-methoxylated intermediate [43,83]. Then, the Cα-O and Cβ-O bonds were simultaneously cleaved and hydrogenated to form the S1 and G1 by the synergistic effects of the catalyst and hydrogen. S3 and S5 were formed by the simultaneous cleavage of the Cα-O, Cγ-O, Cβ-O, and Cβ-H bonds. The double bond might be reduced to a saturated bond in a reducing atmosphere to form the S1 and G2 products. Furthermore, the formation of the ethyl product (S4) might have experienced the cleavage of the Cβ-O and Cβ-Cγ bonds [84]. 4 Conclusions In summary, we have designed a ceria-supported Cu oxide catalyst (CuO/CeO2) for efficient reductive catalytic degradation of lignocellulose lignin into phenolic compounds, affording monomeric yields in 8.8 ∼ 9.6 wt% for softwood lignin and 24.4 ∼ 31.4 wt% for hardwood lignin. The selectivity of the bond cleavage could be effectively controlled by regulation of the reaction conditions, and the selectivity as well as the yield of the product could be controlled by selective cleavage of the ether bond. Experimental results demonstrated that the acidic and basic sites of the CuO/CeO2 catalyst assist the metal sites in the depolymerization of lignin, whereas the acid sites effectively prevented the reunion of reaction intermediates. The synergistic effects of hydrogen and catalyst exhibit high hydrogenolysis activity, which contributes to the efficient C − O bond scission, thus generating the target monomer products. Moreover, it was found that the aliphatic hydroxyl group of the model was methylated, and then the C − O bonds were selectively cleaved to form a monomeric phenol with different side chains. Considering the advantages of establishing a transition metal catalytic system, optimizing more Cu-based catalysts may be more effective in elucidating the mechanism of action, and relevant mechanism studies are in progress. coredata.dc:description: Hydrogenolysis of lignocellulose into renewable phenolic monomers through the reductive catalytic degradation (RCD) strategy is limited by cost and applicability, and there is a need to develop effective catalysts with controlled cost and greater applicability. Herein, we report the fabrication of CuO/CeO2 catalyst toward RCD of lignocellulose for the production of monomeric phenols with different side chains. The catalyst can be adapted to softwoods (Larch and Pinus) and hardwoods (Eucalyptus and Poplar) with yields ranging from 8.8 % to 31.4 %, which afford certain monomer yields while controlling costs. Experimental results demonstrate that the acidic and basic sites of the CuO/CeO2 catalyst assist the metal sites in the depolymerization of lignin. Notably, the mechanistic investigation reveal that the methoxylation process occurs on the aliphatic hydroxyl group. Moreover, the synergistic effects of hydrogen and catalyst exhibit high hydrogenolysis activity, which contributes to the efficient C − O bond scission, thus generating the target monomer products.
